args:
The Officers Academy: a training ground for those
who would one day serve the Alberian royal family.
I longed for knighthood, knowing it would deliver
me from the bottom rung of society I was born into.
Upon enrolling, my acumen was quickly noted.

I never doubted for a second that I was on the path
toward accomplishing my dream. I swore I would
use my platform to create a world where every
human being would be treated equally, regardless
of their birth or social standing.

But all that awaited me was the bitter sting of
reality. Leif and Cecile, both of noble birth,
received stations within the Royal Guard.
Meanwhile, I—a commoner—was doomed to
become part of the worthless Capital Guard.
Harle, I hereby appoint you\nchief of the Capital Guard.
(Pitiful that this is the highest station a\ncommoner could ever hope to reach.)
(There's no future for a country that values\nsocial standing above all. I must enact my\nplan.)
But I must say, I question my father's\nlogic in appointing you as such.
A knight of your skill is far more suited\nto a position within the Royal Guard.
Why, Prince Phares. I am honored that\nyou would think so. Truly, you give me\ntoo much credit.
I only speak the truth. In fact, it is for\nthat reason I have come to you today.
Harle, I would like you to serve\nas my personal guard.
Given your other recent appointment,\nit may be quite the endeavor to take\nboth positions at once—this I recognize.
I am most humbled by your words.\nIf I may ask, what moved you to\napproach a man of my lowly caliber?
Because I believe only you can\nlive up to my expectations.\nDo you accept my offer?
(It sounds too good to be true, but this is\nundoubtedly a tremendous opportunity.)
(I may not know what His Highness's\ntrue intentions are, but I will use him\nin kind.)
I would be a fool to turn down such a\nprivilege. I am yours to command, sir.
Thank you for your hard work, and for seeing\nme home to my research lab. I feel more at \nease here than in the castle.
I would never have guessed that this place\nhoused a laboratory.
Indeed. In the past, I would occasionally\nask him to go on errands for me. The man\nis dependable to a fault, really.
His family has served mine for\ngenerations, so we go back quite\na ways.
Incidentally, I'd been meaning to ask...\nWhat were you doing before you\njoined the Officers Academy?
I was a meager servant for a nobleman.
Interesting. What made you aspire to\nknighthood?

My master at the time was the picture of
magnanimity. He would make any number
of arrangements to see a young man's
future brighten.
You certainly lucked out, didn't you?\nStill, I must caution you against lying.
I beg your pardon? I do not recall\nspinning any falsehoods, Your Highness.
A few years ago, a nobleman was exiled\nafter committing an unspeakable crime.
It sounds like a most terrible incident.\nAnd yet I fail to see what it has to do\nwith present conversation, sir.
Funny you should ask. It happened around\nthe same time you attained knighthood.

Surely a man of your intellect is aware
that if servant were to, say, report his
master's crimes to the crown, he would
be duly rewarded.
And you believe I would do such a thing?\nYou jest. Why, that would be uncivilized.
Ah. My apologies, then. However, an\ninteresting story does spring to mind.\nPerhaps you've heard it.
Not long ago, a messenger arrived from\nGrams for a...secret rendezvous, we'll say.
And who was their contact? My sources\ndescribed him as a knight clad in black.\nWhy, that sounds just like you.

Heavens! What a misunderstanding this is.
I did indeed meet with the messenger in
question, but I was simply showing him
around the capital. I AM chief of its guard.
Oh, is that all? Here I was certain\nyou were sharing intelligence.
You wish to create a world where all\nhuman beings stand shoulder to\nshoulder as equals.
But such a thing is impossible in a\nkingdom with a class system. Therefore...
It would only be natural for you to devise\na plan to destroy this kingdom and build\none that suits your ideals upon its ashes.
You certainly live up to your reputation\nas an esteemed researcher, my liege.\nThat is quite the theory you have crafted.
But I'm afraid a theory is all it is. My\nloyalty lies with the Kingdom of Alberia.
I see. Forgive me—I've always been\nprone to overthinking. Terrible habit.
Now, I must concentrate on my research,\nso please stand by outside for me.

(How much does that man know?!
And if he already pieced all that
together, then why did he take me
on as his personal guard?)
Heh. I think I shall do a little bit of\nresearch of my own, Prince Phares.
Now, if I were looking for information of\nany importance, it would be right...here.
There's got to be something useful... Hm...\nWhat do we have here—an old research\npaper?

The Progenitor... Demons... So he's not
your everyday research scientist after all.
And there's another book shoved into the
back of the shelf...
A child's handwriting, no doubt. It seems\nto be a journal he kept as a child.
＂Day 13, Month of the Lovely Dragon:\nIt appears this will be my final entry.＂

＂My disease continues to plague me.
I suffer from a kind of sensory paralysis.
I lack all strength. My pulse slows.
My hands are ice. My mind is in disarray.＂
Odd. There's no record of the Prince's\ncondition progressing this far in the\nroyal archives.
＂Day 14, Month of the Lovely Dragon:\nI am alive! New strength courses\nthrough my body.＂
He recovered in a single day? Wait... No.\nIf that previous paper is to be believed...
The Progenitor... Reincarnation...\nVessels... An undying body...\nIt can't be!
Now this won't do. You should know\nbetter than to barge into someone's\nprivate study.
I did not peg you as the scholarly type.
Prince Phares... No, perhaps I should\ncall you by the name of the entity living\nwithin you.
I haven't the faintest idea what you mean.\nMore importantly, I have somebody I'd like\nyou to meet. Say hello.
A pleasure to meet you at last.\nFrom now on, I will be known as Harle.
Did you not hear? His name is Harle.\nOh, but there is no need to fret.
Ever since you became my guard, he has\nbeen lurking in the shadows, peering at\nyour memories.
I am certain he will be the perfect\nreplacement for you.
Now I understand. THIS was why you\nwanted me at arm's length.
Those twisted little ideas festering\ninside you suited him quite well.
We couldn't have asked for a better\nperson's life to usurp.
Well, what an honor that is.
Now. You're a smart man. I'm sure\nyou know what must happen next.
There cannot be two Harles in this world.
One moment. If you're just going to kill\nhim, why don't you let me play with him\ninstead?
I've seen into this man's memories.\nHe is QUITE the idealist.
Wouldn't it be exciting to see him crushed\nby the weight of his own foolish notions?
I've no particular interest in such a thing,\nbut by all means, do as you see fit.
No more struggling.\nIt's time we said goodbye.
A tear in space?! Nngh... I'm...\nI'm getting sucked in! AGH!
Farewell, old Harle. Have yourself a\nfun little sojourn in another world.
Ngh... Where is this? Am I...still alive?
What a desolate place...\nWhere in the world did they dump me?
That volcano... Am I in Valkaheim?
Heed me, my subjects! The Kingdom of\nAlberia has at last been unified under\nthe eldest of its royals, Leonidas!
Hail our unity! Hail King Leonidas!
(Prince Leonidas did what? Nonsense.\nI've never heard anything about this.)
Listen well as we elucidate the new status\nquo. Prime Minister, if you would?
